description: Canonical entity registry for Regen Network - FULLY AUTOMATED

automation.note: This file is auto-generated. Edit overrides.json to make corrections.

C01.name: Verified Carbon Standard
C01.description: This credit class provides a vehicle for nature based Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) to enter the blockchain space via issuance on Regen Ledger. It can be used by project developers, credit brokers, and other stakeholders interested in digitizing carbon credits issued by the VCS program to make them available in the emerging world of decentralized finance.

C02.name: Urban Forest Carbon Credit Class
C02.description:
City Forest Credits is the national standard for greenhouse gas emission reduction and removal for tree projects in cities and towns. Developed by leading scientists, industry, and urban forest professionals, the Standard and Protocols define the set of rules and requirements that tree preservation projects must follow in order to earn third-party verified carbon credits.

CFC has a 40-year and a 100-year Tree Preservation Protocol, modeled after avoided conversion or avoided emissions protocols in forestry. The 40-year Protocol was designed for the voluntary market and the 100-year Protocol for the compliance market in the state of California.

C03.name: TCO2: Toucan Carbon Tokens Credit Class
C03.description: This credit class provides a vehicle for Toucan Protocol Toucan Carbon Tokens (TCO2s) to enter the Cosmos ecosystem via issuance on Regen Ledger. Each TCO2 represents a unique carbon offset brought on-chain from the Verra registry using the Toucan Carbon Bridge. Currently, only TCO2 credits that fall under the NCT criteria are eligible to be issued under this credit class. Eligible credits can be bridged directly from Polygon using the Regen Network <> Toucan Bridge.

C04.name: Ruuts Credit Class for Soil Carbon Sequestration through Regenerative Grazing
aliases: Credit Class for Soil Carbon Sequestration through Regenerative Grazing
C04.description: The Credit Class and its accompanying methodology provide farmers with a measuring and monitoring process for soil organic carbon sequestration in regenerative grazing systems, enabling them to generate carbon credits that also include robust ecological co-benefits such as water infiltration and biodiversity.

KSH01.name: Credit Class for Sheep Grazing in Vineyard Systems
aliases: Class for Sheep Grazing in Vineyard Systems
KSH01.description: This Credit Class and its accompanying methodology are designed to support the use of high-density, short-duration rotational targeted sheep grazing in vineyard systems to improve ecosystem functioning through active management of the soil and herbaceous cover in the vineyard understory. As with other Environmental Stewardship methodologies, the environmental benefits are implicit in the practice. Projects being developed under the Methodology for Grazing in Vineyard Systems are expected, based on prior research, to result in positive ecological outcomes. This methodology is new and innovative, and will be improved as new projects are created and lessons are learned.

C05.name: Credit Class for Carbon Removal through Biochar Production
C05.description: The Biochar Carbon credit focuses on carbon removal and avoiding emissions that would have resulted from the decomposition of waste biomass. Carbon removal is the approved benefit that is monitored, quantified, and determines the number of credits issued. The approved benefit of atmospheric regulation through carbon sequestration is driven by carbon removals and reductions through the production and application of biochar to soils.

C06.name: GHG Benefits in Managed Crop and Grassland Systems Credit Class
aliases: Benefits in Managed Crop and Grassland Systems Credit Class
C06.description: This Credit Class and its supporting measuring and monitoring methodology, focuses on quantifying increases in soil organic carbon sequestration and storage in regenerative cropping and managed grassland agricultural systems.

C07.name: CarbonPlus Grasslands Credit Class
C07.description: This Credit Class provide incentive and a structure to significantly increase the amount of hectares/acres under managed grazing worldwide by providing land stewards with the necessary incentives to make this important work possible. The CarbonPlus credit focuses on soil carbon sequestration in grassland ecosystems. The Plus indicates that co-benefits (or secondary ecological benefits) allow for a credit that accounts for more than just carbon.

BT01.name: Terrasos Biodiversity Unit
BT01.description:
The Biodioversity Credits protocol outlines a strategic framework for the development of projects that guarantee quantifiable gains in biodiversity, all while providing robust financial and legal assurances to secure their sustainability and enduring impact. This pioneering approach to biodiversity conservation and resource management emphasizes the selection of projects distinguished by their significant ecological value within a performance-based model. 
 This protocol streamlines the process of registration, quantification, and issuance of Biodiversity Credits (VBC) for conservation projects that meet the eligibility criteria. It is designed to resonate with both individuals and organizations committed to contributing to the preservation of threatened ecosystems and biodiversity, ultimately delivering long-term sustainability and socio-economic benefits.

MBS01.name: SeaTrees Crediting Protocol for Marine Restoration
MBS01.description: This protocol is designed to help local communities scale the restoration of degraded nearshore ecosystems and provide direct market access to philanthropic, donation-based funding via biodiversity credits called SeaTrees Biodiversity Blocks. It is a roadmap for designing effective marine restoration projects that can be funded via the insurance of voluntary biodiversity credits. This protocol also contains three ecosystem-specific modules, which provide guidelines and best-practices for restoring coral reefs, mangrove forests, and kelp forests. This protocol does not allow issuance of carbon credits or biodiversity offsets.

USS01.name: Biodiversity Credit Protocol for Umbrella Species Stewardship
aliases: Credit Protocol for Umbrella Species Stewardship
USS01.description: The Biodiversity Crediting Protocol for Umbrella Species Stewardship (USS) provides a comprehensive framework for measuring, verifying, and rewarding communities for their conservation of umbrella species—organisms whose protection benefits entire ecosystems and their inhabitants. The protocol measures conservation success through three integrated components: Umbrella Species Health, which tracks population dynamics and distribution; Habitat Quality, which assesses ecosystem composition and function; and a Theory of Change, which translates community knowledge and long-term goals into strategic conservation activities. By combining on-the-ground data collection, remote sensing, and traditional ecological knowledge, the protocol enables scientifically rigorous and transparent verification of conservation outcomes. All ecological data anchors securely to a blockchain, ensuring credible, verifiable proof of impact. The USS credits represent actual implementation costs, directly linking conservation finance to real biodiversity gains while preventing speculative trading. This empowers local communities and land stewards to address critical biodiversity threats and strengthens their essential role in long-term ecosystem stewardship.

C08.name: Nature-Based Watershed & Green Infrastructure Solutions to Avoid Gray Infrastructure Emissions
aliases: Watershed & Green Infrastructure Solutions to Avoid Gray Infrastructure Emissions
C08.description: This Credit Class enables Project Proponents to generate carbon credits by reducing nonpoint source contamination of watersheds, thereby avoiding the increased greenhouse gas emissions from the status-quo infrastructure construction and electricity use associated with industrial drinking water and wastewater management and treatment. Project Proponents quantify reduction in GHG emissions associated with the avoided energy and materials from the gray infrastructure that green solutions replace - including construction materials, decades of operational energy use, and facility maintenance. Credits issue annually ex-post throughout the avoided infrastructure's lifetime, representing permanent emission reductions achieved when watersheds naturally filter and treat water, making industrial treatment infrastructure unnecessary while improving ecosystem health.

C09.name: GHG & Co-Benefits in Watershed Carbon
C09.description: This Credit Class generates carbon credits by reducing nonpoint source contamination of watersheds, thereby avoiding increased greenhouse gas emissions from construction and operation of gray water infrastructure. Credits are issued for avoided emissions from energy and material use in drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater management facilities.

BT01-001.name: El Globo Habitat Bank
BT01-001.description: El Globo is the first project in Colombia to issue Voluntary Biodiversity Credits. It is located in the "Cuchilla Jardín-Támesis" Integrated Management District (DMI). Known as the "water star" of southwestern Antioquia, this area is a prioritized ecosystem for conservation. Here ecosystem preservation, forest enhancement and restoration activities are implemented to generate positive and permanent impacts on biodiversity. The project has a 30-year financial, technical and legal structure for operation, securing biodiversity gains in time. The area has one of the few remnants of Native High Andean Forest still preserved in the region and it is a registered Habitat Bank at the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development of Colombia.

BT01-002.name: Aguadulce Habitat Bank
BT01-002.description: Aguadulce – Río Sumapaz Habitat Bank, located in the province of Alto Magdalena, Cundinamarca, Colombia, spans over 124.76 hectares and aims to preserve and restore two key ecosystems: tropical dry forest and premontane humid forest. Through this initiative, Terrasos promotes biodiversity conservation and offers biodiversity credits to offset environmental impacts. This project offers an opportunity for buyers to contribute to the protection of endangered species while supporting ecosystem restoration.

C05-001.name: San Juan Carbon Project
C05-001.description: The San Juan Islands Garry Oak Restoration Burns Project focuses on producing biochar from waste biomass in Washington's San Juan Islands. By converting wood waste gathered from wildfire prevention and invasive species control efforts into biochar, this project sequesters carbon, reduces GHG emissions, and restores native Garry Oak woodlands. The in-stand biochar application enhances soil health and supports long-term carbon storage.

C06-001.name: Philipson Estate Blaston
C06-001.description: GHG Benefits in Managed Crop and Grassland Systems Credit Class project in England, UK

C06-002.name: Pimlico Farm
C06-002.description: The primary indicator in this credit class is SOCS. Levels will be increased by growing harvestable and cover crops and grass to maximise canopy and root growth while incorporating crop residues and manures. Reduced soil disturbance, maintaining soil cover and returning crop residues will maximise retained organic matter (OM) in the soil and, through improved soil microbial activity, this will be converted to resilient SOC.

C07-001.name: Woodburn
C07-001.description: Woodburn is a beef breeding operation situated north of Walcha on the New England tablelands of Australia. The grasslands here grow on basalt and sandy loam soils and host Woodburn's high density herds of cattle. Considerable investments have been made at Woodburn to improve fencing and water infrastructure, enabling for an increase in animal density integral to prescribed grazing. Continued improvement in the ecological state of the farm is core to how Woodburn is managed.

C07-002.name: Cavan Station
C07-002.description: Cavan Station is on the southern tablelands of New South Wales, Australia. Divided by the Murrumbidgee River at Yass, it comprises a diverse range of landscapes including limestone rocky outcrops, undulating slopes and steep native vegetated hills. The Cavan Station angus cow herd has been developed over the past 20 years on the harsh Southern Tablelands environment and steep limestone hills. The lands are managed with time controlled rotational grazing.

C08-001.name: Yahara WINS Watershed Carbon Project
C08-001.description: The Yahara WINS Watershed Carbon Project implements nature-based and green infrastructure practices that avoid emissions from construction and operation of gray wastewater infrastructure. Through an adaptive management approach, the project reduces nutrient loads via agricultural and watershed best management practices—including cover crops, conservation cover, grassed waterways, wetland restoration, and structural erosion control measures—thereby avoiding the need for a tertiary/advanced filtration upgrade at the Nine Springs Wastewater Treatment Plant. Project Proponents quantify reduction in GHG emissions associated with the avoided energy and materials from the gray infrastructure that green solutions replace, including construction materials, decades of operational energy use, and facility maintenance. Credits issue annually ex-post throughout the avoided infrastructure's lifetime.

KSH01-001.name: Grgich Hills Estate Regenerative Sheep Grazing
KSH01-001.description: Credit Class for Sheep Grazing in Vineyard Systems project in California, USA

MBS01-001.name: Mangrove Forest: Marereni
MBS01-001.description: Empowering local communities to plant and protect mangrove ecosystems in Marereni, Kilifi, Kenya

USS01-001.name: Jaguar Stewardship in the Pantanal Conservation Network
aliases: Stewardship in the Pantanal Conservation Network
USS01-001.description: The Instituto Homem Pantaneiro (IHP) is an NGO dedicated to preserving the Brazilian Pantanal biome, considered the largest continental wetland on the planet and a Natural World Heritage Site. IHP conducts a range of activities to improve ecosystem health and jaguar habitat, including: managing protected areas, firefighting, monitoring biodiversity and deforestation, conducting research, and facilitating dialogue among stakeholders. One credit represents a composite measure of biodiversity stewardship effectiveness, focused on jaguars as an umbrella species, across a 40,613-hectare private conservation reserve, based on a Theory of Change established by ERA and IHP. The project combines advanced monitoring technologies with community engagement to address key threats, particularly wildfires which affected over 90% of the Serra do Amolar region in 2020.

USS01-002.name: Biocultural Jaguar Credits, Ancestral Stewardship in the Sharamentsa Community
aliases: Jaguar Credits, Ancestral Stewardship in the Sharamentsa Community
USS01-002.description: A biocultural conservation project led by the Sharamentsa community of the Achuar Nation, protecting jaguar habitat in the Ecuadorian Amazon through land management and community-based monitoring. This pilot initiative demonstrates a new ecological-economic model aligning biodiversity conservation with cultural integrity and local well-being.
